t: Habakkuk 1
The*p burden which the prophet Habakkuk saw.
The Prophet’s Question
O*pn Lord,*s how long shall I cry, And*ld You will not hear? Even*ld cry out to You, “Violence!” And*ld You will not save.
Why*ld do You show me iniquity, And*ld cause me*i to see trouble? For*ld plundering and violence are*i before me; There*ld is strife, and contention arises.
Therefore*ld the law is powerless, And*ld justice never goes forth. For*ld the wicked surround the righteous; Therefore*ld perverse judgment proceeds.
The Lord’s Reply
“Look*pn among the nations and watch— Be*ld utterly astounded! For*ld I*i will*i work a work in your days Which*ild you would not believe, though it were told you.*i
For*ld indeed I am raising up the Chaldeans, A*ld bitter and hasty nation Which*ld marches through the breadth of the earth, To*ld possess dwelling places that*i are*i not theirs.
They*ld are terrible and dreadful; Their*ld judgment and their dignity proceed from themselves.

Their*ld horses also are swifter than leopards, And*ld more fierce than evening wolves. Their*ld chargers charge ahead; Their*ld cavalry comes from afar; They*ld fly as the eagle that*i hastens to eat.
“They*ln all come for violence; Their*ld faces are set like*i the east wind. They*ld gather captives like sand.
They*ld scoff at kings, And*ld princes are scorned by them. They*ld deride every stronghold, For*ld they heap up earthen mounds*i and seize it.
Then*ld his*i mind changes, and he transgresses; He*ld commits offense, Ascribing*ild this power to his god.”
The Prophet’s Second Question
Are*pn You not from everlasting, O*ld Lord*s my God, my Holy One? We*ld shall not die. O*ld Lord,*s You have appointed them for judgment; O*ld Rock, You have marked them for correction.

You*ild are*i of purer eyes than to behold evil, And*ld cannot look on wickedness. Why*ld do You look on those who deal treacherously, And*ild hold Your tongue when the wicked devours A*ld person*i more righteous than he?
Why*ild do You make men like fish of the sea, Like*ld creeping things that*i have*i no ruler over them?
They*ln take up all of them with a hook, They*ld catch them in their net, And*ld gather them in their dragnet. Therefore*ld they rejoice and are glad.
Therefore*ld they sacrifice to their net, And*ld burn incense to their dragnet; Because*ld by them their share is*i sumptuous And*ld their food plentiful.
Shall*ld they therefore empty their net, And*ld continue to slay nations without pity?
Habakkuk 2
I*pn will stand my watch And*ld set myself on the rampart, And*ld watch to see what He will say to me, And*ld what I will answer when I am corrected.
The Just Live by Faith
Then*p the Lord*s answered me and said: “Write*pn the vision And*ld make it*i plain on tablets, That*ld he may run who reads it.
For*ld the vision is*i yet for an appointed time; But*ld at the end it will speak, and it will not lie. Though*ld it tarries, wait for it; Because*ld it will surely come, It*ld will not tarry.
“Behold*ln the proud, His*ld soul is not upright in him; But*ld the just shall live by his faith.
Woe to the Wicked

“Indeed,*pn because he transgresses by wine, He*ild is*i a proud man, And*ld he does not stay at home. Because*ld he enlarges his desire as hell, And*ld he is*i like death, and cannot be satisfied, He*ld gathers to himself all nations And*ld heaps up for himself all peoples.

“Will*ln not all these take up a proverb against him, And*ld a taunting riddle against him, and say, ‘Woe*ld to him who increases What*ild is not his—how long? And*ld to him who loads himself with many pledges’?
Will*ld not your creditors rise up suddenly? Will*ld they not awaken who oppress you? And*ld you will become their booty.

Because*ld you have plundered many nations, All*ld the remnant of the people shall plunder you, Because*ld of men’s blood And*ld the violence of the land and*i the city, And*ld of all who dwell in it.
“Woe*ln to him who covets evil gain for his house, That*ld he may set his nest on high, That*ld he may be delivered from the power of disaster!
You*ld give shameful counsel to your house, Cutting*ld off many peoples, And*ld sin against*i your soul.
For*ld the stone will cry out from the wall, And*ld the beam from the timbers will answer it.
“Woe*ln to him who builds a town with bloodshed, Who*ld establishes a city by iniquity!
Behold,*ld is*i it*i not of the Lord*s of hosts That*ld the peoples labor to feed the fire, And*ld nations weary themselves in vain?
For*ld the earth will be filled With*ld the knowledge of the glory of the Lord,*s As*ld the waters cover the sea.
“Woe*ln to him who gives drink to his neighbor, Pressing*ld him*i to*i your bottle, Even*ld to make him*i drunk, That*ld you may look on his nakedness!

You*ld are filled with shame instead of glory. You*ld also—drink! And*ld be exposed as uncircumcised! The*ld cup of the Lord’s*s right hand will*i be*i turned against you, And*ld utter shame will be on your glory.

For*ld the violence done*i to*i Lebanon will cover you, And*ld the plunder of beasts which*i made them afraid, Because*ld of men’s blood And*ld the violence of the land and*i the city, And*ld of all who dwell in it.
“What*ln profit is the image, that its maker should carve it, The*ld molded image, a teacher of lies, That*ld the maker of its mold should trust in it, To*ld make mute idols?
Woe*ld to him who says to wood, ‘Awake!’ To*ld silent stone, ‘Arise! It shall teach!’ Behold,*ld it is overlaid with gold and silver, Yet*ld in it there is no breath at all.
“But*ln the Lord*s is in His holy temple. Let*ld all the earth keep silence before Him.”
Habakkuk 3
The Prophet’s Prayer
A*p prayer of Habakkuk the prophet, on Shigionoth.
O*pn Lord,*s I have heard Your speech and*i was afraid; O*ld Lord,*s revive Your work in the midst of the years! In*ld the midst of the years make it*i known; In*ld wrath remember mercy.
God*ln came from Teman, The*ld Holy One from Mount Paran. Selah*ipg His*pn glory covered the heavens, And*ld the earth was full of His praise.
His*ild brightness was like the light; He*ld had rays flashing*i from His hand, And*ld there His power was*i hidden.
Before*ld Him went pestilence, And*ld fever followed at His feet.
He*ln stood and measured the earth; He*ld looked and startled the nations. And*ld the everlasting mountains were scattered, The*ld perpetual hills bowed. His*ld ways are*i everlasting.
I*ld saw the tents of Cushan in affliction; The*ld curtains of the land of Midian trembled.
O*ln Lord,*s were You*i displeased with the rivers, Was*ild Your anger against the rivers, Was*ild Your wrath against the sea, That*ld You rode on Your horses, Your*ld chariots of salvation?
Your*ld bow was made quite ready; Oaths*ld were sworn over Your*i arrows. Selah*ipg You*pn divided the earth with rivers.
The*ld mountains saw You and*i trembled; The*ld overflowing of the water passed by. The*ld deep uttered its voice, And*ild lifted its hands on high.
The*ld sun and moon stood still in their habitation; At*ld the light of Your arrows they went, At*ld the shining of Your glittering spear.
You*ld marched through the land in indignation; You*ld trampled the nations in anger.
You*ld went forth for the salvation of Your people, For*ld salvation with Your Anointed. You*ld struck the head from the house of the wicked, By*ld laying bare from foundation to neck. Selah*ipg
You*pn thrust through with his own arrows The*ld head of his villages. They*ld came out like a whirlwind to scatter me; Their*ld rejoicing was like feasting on the poor in secret.
You*ld walked through the sea with Your horses, Through*ld the heap of great waters.

When*ln I heard, my body trembled; My*ld lips quivered at the*i voice; Rottenness*ld entered my bones; And*ld I trembled in myself, That*ld I might rest in the day of trouble. When*ld he comes up to the people, He*ld will invade them with his troops.
A Hymn of Faith

Though*pn the fig tree may not blossom, Nor*ld fruit be on the vines; Though*ld the labor of the olive may fail, And*ld the fields yield no food; Though*ld the flock may be cut off from the fold, And*ld there be no herd in the stalls—
Yet*ld I will rejoice in the Lord,*s I*ld will joy in the God of my salvation.
The*ln Lord*s God is my strength; He*ld will make my feet like deer’s feet,*i And*ld He will make me walk on my high hills. To*p the Chief Musician. With my stringed instruments.
